Fields.DialogueText: Either I'm more sleep-deprived than I thought I was....
And how likely do you think that is, Captain?
... Or you're telling me that two Sins got through the Kattegatt.
I *wish* I was telling you that.
It's *three* Sins, Kanchou. And the third one's a doozy.
Define "doozy."
Her aircraft look different from the Sins we've run into so far. Spikier.
Nobody's gotten any good pictures yet.
Maybe you'll be the first.
Maybe. What I want to know is what we've got to throw at her.
Well, the League's still trying to coordinate things, but we're spread pretty thin. Most of the fleets round here are national, not International.

Fields.MenuText: The Soviet Baltic Fleet might have some forces to spare, the push on Finland notwithstanding.
Can we count on the Allies to do anything here?

Fields.DialogueText: Yeah. The Hearst papers with a Russian accent.
Here's the other way to think about it: they're fighting off Morganas on two fronts - three if the Morganas can work through the ice in the Arctic Circle - and they picked a fight with Finland, too.
This your idea of a joke, Captain?
I hadn't realized writing an unwelcome story for the Capitalist Pig Gazette could get you on a slow train to Siberia.
Right. Sounds like we've got our work cut out for us.
We always do.
This has not been the best war for them.
The writers at Pravda and Izvestia would strenuously disagree. And the worse it gets the more strenuous the disagreement will be.
I just want to see what options we've got.
As far as we're concerned? Allied help isn't an option. We're going to have to find friends somewhere else.
*ALARM*
Hand-cut and delivered. Will wonders never cease?
Stations, people! She's already in firing range.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: We can always count on the INPF, right?

Fields.DialogueText: That and a prayer will get you to the back of the breadline.
Vzdor! I'm sure our very dear comrades in Switzerland will join hands in the great harmony of brotherhood any day now.
So we can hope the Kriegsmarine is in one of its cooperative phases -
Historically, they've tended to have those when they're not in radio contact with their superiors, Captain.
If they're in shouting range of Danzig, I doubt they'll get an okay to make life too easy on the Soviets.
And here I thought they were all buddies.
Germany was quietly backing the Finns even before Warsaw fell. They may not be fighting the Soviets directly, but I don't think they're rooting for Stalin to have a glorious triumph here either.
I was being sarcastic.
Yeah, well. We've already established I'm sleep deprived.
Plus, of course, the League wants us supporting their investigation into human collaboration with the Morganas across the Baltic-
- And the Germans hate the idea that somebody would use the Soviet-Finnish war as a pretext for snooping into what *they* were up to around the Hel Peninsula.
They probably actively want both us and the Soviets to go down in flames.
... And if the skies go daaark and the mighty ocean swelllllls...
Listening to the radio again, Kirishima?
Oh! I didn't see you there, Kanchou!
What're all these photographs?
Sin! I put the word out.
You wanted pictures of her?
I wanted pictures of all the Morganas when they first arrived, and well... I got three boxes. And most of this first box was Sin.
The Morganas arriving, huh...
Any clue helps, doesn't it? And there's a lot of clues! I can't figure out exactly to what yet, but it's on the tip of my tongue, I just know it-
Whoa, whoa, easy there. Who got you these?
Some of them were from Belles. Some of them were from crewmates with a hobby. And some of them...
... were from our very own Mr. Lugin. Or his shady friends, at least.

Fields.MenuText: Doesn't surprise me. What've you learnt so far?

Fields.DialogueText: It's hard to make out much. There are a few standout shots, but mostly I'm just seeing the fog and the light. Do you think Morganas are camera shy?

Fields.MenuText: It'd make our lives easier if they were.
I think mist doesn't play nice with lenses.
Eh, I think this photographer got a pretty good view of her.

Fields.DialogueText: You're probably right. It'd be more fun if the explanation was more exciting.
You're right. ...That's definitely an... angle they got her at... And a position...
It's certainly... unique. Is her spine at a right angle?
Ano... You think Morganas are made of rubber, Kanchou?
It wouldn't surprise me. At this point, nothing would.
I'm just imagining a hundred cameras on the deck of every ship. It'd almost make me feel sorry for them.
Don't turn into a sympathizer on me.
I did say 'almost'!
Maybe we should be grateful it isn't. The easier it is to understand, the easier we can know our enemy.
Like I said, you're right.
Anyway. ...You said Lugin got you these?
About half this box.
Who got you the other half?
August's friend Lew.
"August"?
Ah! Don't tease me, Kanchou.
I wasn't teasing. Just observing.
Y-you'll have to talk to A-Mr. Cassel about this. He knows Lew better than I do.
*ALARM*
That's a conversation that can wait. Get to the engine room.
Yes! Right away!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Damn. We might want to make a more formal arrangement with some of these people. This one's superb.

Fields.DialogueText: And we just heard from her the other day, so she probably hasn't gotten arrested for anything yet!
... I'd laugh at that, but...
But we all know Lugin's shady friends lead totally exciting lives.
That's one way to put it. Anyway - learned anything interesting?
-- and Wegrzyn's fully on board. He's still trying to get some of his contacts to trust us...
Because nothing can ever be that simple.
No. But I'm making a little headway.
Certainment. And it doesn't help at all that he's your cousin.
Second cousin. We're not close.
Still. You really all know each other, don't you?
August! Are you busy?
A bit, yes.
Well, if you can put ... whatever this is... down for a second... there's an absolutely beautiful Morgana wreck off the prow!
And you want me to come see?
"Whatever this is" is mission-critical.
I really hope you're not implying what I think you're implying.
It sounded a lot more like gossip to me.
I'd act shocked that you learnt nothing from Fanny, but at this point, I can't even pretend--
I wasn't about to say "cabal," if that's what you mean. It's a small world. And it's smaller when you have common...  interests.
I mean, if you have a second...  Especially since the sun's setting...
I learnt plenty of things!
Hey, what's going on? I hear raised voices.
Nothing important! We were just talking.
... Uh-huh.
We were having a discussion about intelligence assets. Mademoiselle Kirishima... had some inanity to share.

Fields.MenuText: "Military intelligence" is always an oxymoron.
You two can keep at it. I had orders for Kirishima anyway.
Would it kill you not to disrespect your fellow crewmates?

Fields.DialogueText: Then it's a good thing neither of us are going through military channels.
Dieu merci.
You could ask her the same question, Capitaine.
I could and will.
Belay that.
It is.
I'd be nicer to her if she wasn't so -- so--
We *were* in the middle of something. Sayako... Captain... If it's something really urgent, of course...
Mm, I was just looking for a status report.
... And I just wanted to see if you wanted to see the wreckage. Before the sun's done setting.
*ALARM*
Looks like we'll see plenty of wreckage tonight...
... It's really not the same...
@BATTLE
That stack of letters is the size of your torso.
Mm! And this isn't even all of them, I left half of them in my bunk.
Are they *all* from Belles?
Most of them. I've been talking a lot to the French Belles, and one of them promised to get me in touch with her sister who's an artist--
Well, that's good. Keep up the good work.
Kanchou, can I ask you a personal question?
Shoot.
Eeto... well... does everyone have an easier time talking to Belles than to people, or is it just me?

Fields.MenuText: Belles are people. But I get what you mean.
You're unique that way, yes.
To be entirely fair, the humans aboard this ship are a bit...

Fields.DialogueText: Yokatta. It's good to know I'm not the only one.
... I wish I could argue, but you're right.
I'm not sure whether the humans or the Belles are stranger, you're right.
... It doesn't help that you have some baggage with most of the folks aboard.
It's mostly just Savary-san. I get along well enough with everyone else.
Even August?
That was a low blow, Kanchou.
All I'm saying is, you need to talk to some folks. Sort some things out. Clear the air.
I've been trying.
If you have to, pretend they're Belles.
*ALARM*
Oh! We'd better get back to work.
There's always more to do.
@BATTLE
Out for a smoke? Mind if I join you?
Not at all. I'm waiting on the paper.
They're three days old by the time they get to us.
Ever the optimist.
I just looked at the date. -- "State of the Union", huh?
Mmm. Roosevelt's big speech.
What's with that look?

Fields.MenuText: I know you're not exactly a... blind patriot.
That's not the kind of news you usually care about.
So that's why you were mad we weren't getting good reception.

Fields.DialogueText: Was it that obvious?
We haven't been in American airspace, but I hoped I could catch *something*.
It isn't usually worth caring about.
So what's different this time?
That's an understatement.
I'm not trying to insult you.
No, it's fine. I left *that* kind of faith back in Harlem.
Why do you care so much about this speech?
You keep asking who our allies are, Captain. What we've got to work with.
The US has never been a member of the League. Still aren't, technically.
I wanted to catch the big speech to see if that was going to change.
Well, did it?
Not in so many words. But Roosevelt's sure making some noises that way.
Higher defense spending, higher taxes, common sense, Constitution won't die in vain... everything you'd expect.
Well, that's good, right?
... Depends on where it goes.
How do you figure?
Permission to get political?
Granted.
Everything America does, it's out of fear.
Folks are scared of another crash, or scared of another war, or scared someone somewhere's getting more than they got.
That's how the world goes, isn't it...
Yeah. But...
How this breaks. Whether America helps the League. Whether they join the land war.
It's all gonna depend on what they're afraid of.
Didn't Roosevelt say the only thing we have to fear is fear itself?
Yeah.
So that's good for us. Considering who we're fighting...
Wish I had your faith, Captain.
*ALARM*
Well, here comes fear herself.
Let's hope she doesn't mess up my paper. I wanted to *finish* one for once.
@BATTLE
What're you in the sickbay for?
Such suspicion. I thought we were brothers in arms.
That wasn't suspicion, that was... curiosity? Sympathy?
Razve? It's hard to tell those things apart.
I don't think any of us know anything about you. And we've been on the same ship for how many months?
Maybe that's just how I like it.
And two can play at this game, my friend. What are you doing in the sick bay, mm?
Do *you* have something to declare?
... Please don't shout.
Ah, are you hung over? I have a cure for that. You'll need a sparrow--
And some pickle juice, and of course some brandy. Hair of the dog, the Americans say. And then-
... I haven't been drinking, nee. And after that, uh, I'm not sure I ever want to.
You didn't even wait to hear what the sparrow was for. I'm almost offended.
I'm sorry you feel that way. ...Oof.
Here's your damn pills, Cassel. I hope you appreciate what we had to do to get them.
Thank you so much. -- Was it that bad?
With how supply lines have been, it'd be easier to get morphine.
With present company aboard, I believe you. -- *gulp*
If you *do* want something stronger--
I've got to keep my head clear. Thanks, though.
My contacts need a careful hand.
Cassel? Is everything --
I'm fine, Captain. Just had a headache.
I couldn't help but overhear-- are we that short on aspirin?
Nein. Nothing like that.

Fields.MenuText: So it's something stronger.
Do I need to be worried?
Must be some headache.

Fields.DialogueText: What makes you say that, Kapitän? I'm fine.
If you're getting special medicine...
Not stronger as much as... different.
The regular stuff doesn't work. This does.
Nein. I have them under control.
Well, if there's anything I can do...
*ALARM*
*Ow.*
Get back in there, Cassel. You're in no shape to fight.
... Ja, Kapitän.
Not even going to argue?
There's an ice pick directly between my eyes. Would you want to argue?
Under those conditions? Nyet. ...You've been having trouble getting those pills? What're they called?
Ergotamine... uh, tartrate.
And you can't get more? Koshmar.
... Nein. Why are you asking?
Just curiosity, friend. Go get that ice pick out of your face.
@BATTLE
All right, folks, this is an information briefing. Operating conditions have changed.
Soviet operations in Finland have broken down. Last night, Kombrig Vinogradov ordered a retreat. As of 12:00 today, the region's under Finnish control.
Our mission parameters are the same - keep the Morganas off the coasts and away from civilian populations.
The extra wrinkle is that we've got Soviet deserters-
- And stragglers who got driven back. The Morganas may target them, trying to absorb their manpower and materiel.
We run into any of them, we take them aboard.
The Morganas *will* try and take advantage of this, and we need to make that as hard as possible.
You've all made it this far. You've done good work. I'm confident you can handle this situation, even with the new wrinkles.
All right. Back to work.
Kapitän. A word?
Course, Lugin. What's eating you?
You have been asking *me* to liase with the Kremlin...
Mm. I know you're not excited about it, but we need someone who speaks fluent Russian.
"Not excited," the Kapitän says. "Not excited" is for when you are stranded in the desert with a camel who licks your ear in your sleep.
If I speak with important people, it is hazardous to the health of everyone involved.
In a world where things were as they should be, I would never see or be seen by the good and the great.
Are you going somewhere with this?
You have some nerve, Kapitän.
Me? What did I do here?
You tell me, "Ah, yes, Lugin, your cooperation is viiiital to the success of our missssssion, we neeeeeed you to talk to people who see you as a bug on their shooooe."
And then you tell us, "ah yes, this political torpedo, one of the terrible American ones that explodes if you poke it? Yes, we will fire that directly at Moscow."

Fields.MenuText: This isn't a political decision, this is a tactical one.
I know it's not the wisest course of action. We'll mitigate it.
It's the right thing to do.

Fields.DialogueText: "Mitigate it." How? Do you have a plan?
You're always an idealist. But even for you, this is foolish.
I thought you'd know better, Kapitän. In your line of work, there's no such thing as a decision without politics.
Well, not yet. I was going to talk to you-
Do you have any idea how much materiel the Red Army's left behind?
I swear, it's not.
Of course you were. Of course.
Enough. My more... vulturish comrades are dancing in the streets.
They can do that because the Red Army left behind an entire marching band.
... Why am I unsurprised?
I don't think the Morganas are going to run off with a tuba any time soon-
Can you even imagine? Don't ask me why, but Cowardice-
But if they could grab the person who was supposed to play it? They'd absolutely love more "crew."
... I know that. You know that. Every Kapitän and sailor from here to Australia knows that.
But the big bosses, the ones with more medals than chest? It's their job not to know that.
So what do you propose we do?
If I was, as the Americans say, in your shoes? I would have ignored all this.
At least publicly. But we can't do that now.

Fields.MenuText: So you're saying we give up the deserters?
So you're saying we shut up and fly under their noses.
So you're saying we apologize?

Fields.DialogueText: They can't allow soldiers to run away, and the cost of the punishment is less, to them, than the loss of manpower.
Nyet, that puts you in a position of weakness.
If you can. How long you can, well, I don't know about that.
Absolutely not. No.
There is no good solution to the problem you've put us in. You made our bed. You set it on fire.
And now I must cry in it. And *perhaps* my tears will put out the flames.
*ALARM*
We'll figure this out. We always do.
I'd be more encouraged if you said that *before* the alarms.
@BATTLE
You mean rescuing Soviet refugees, who may or may not include deserters.
"May or may not?"
... It just keeps getting better.
Reports from the Helgoland mess are still... not entirely clear. But it certainly sounds like the Germans sank Gloire, Belle and all.
I'm confused. Haven't the Germans already been attacking Allied ships?
Yes. But because of the Morganas, they haven't been as... aggressive as they might have been. And the Zurich Agreement is supposed to forbid Belle-on-Belle violence.
So we've had a lot more warning shots than we might have. A lot more driving ships back. A lot more disruption. But the-
A lot less murder?
That's a whole conversation that nobody seems to know enough to have.
What's to know? Sinking a Belle is pretty much killing her. Even if she can come back.
It's war, Sayako. Belles are combatants.
Yes, but-
Gloire was part of an attack on a German installation on Heligoland that seems to have been stuffed with active Morgana technology. Allies say she was right to attack under the League mandate.
... It's a damn shame. I thought after last month, they'd decided to be halfway productive.
You really don't want to hear what I have to say about that, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe I do. Maybe I'll even agree.
I don't, but you're going to tell me anyway.
Even if we don't agree, you think through what you say. Lay it on me.

Fields.DialogueText: You just have to shut me up to keep your bosses happy. I understand.
I know how to keep my mouth shut. Believe me. But this is important.
Danke schön, Kapitän.
So what's on your mind?
... The Germans, they cooperated with you because it was useful to them.
No one knew what to do with the Morgana thumpers. You came in with a head full of crazy ideas and told them you could fix it. So they listened.
They did. And I hope they'll keep listening.
They will, right up until you get in the way of their ambitions.

Fields.MenuText: Cassel... I think you're a little biased.
That's just politics. You move around everyone's ambitions.
So we plan around those ambitions.

Fields.DialogueText: ... You can't plan around the destruction of anything that isn't them.
It is and it isn't.
Next you're going to tell me that rabbits are biased against wolves.
... Politics aside.
We need to open communication channels back up with the OKM. And with the Red Navy, both. This can't keep happening.
You're going to have to talk to Lugin about that one. ...Where is he?
He's been almost as hard to find as you have, Augie.
Augie?
*ALARM*
Well, at least someone's easy to find when you need her.
When you "need" her?
Sometimes a conversation just needs to die.
@BATTLE
Germans say they were entitled to defend their facility.
Never mind the fact that - at best - they were recklessly using technology we don't understand with potentially calamitous effects. And possibly using slave labor to get it up and running.
... Ugh. This is ridiculous.
What is, Kanchou?
Ah! How'd you get in here?
You left the door open. Maybe that's how so many Belles keep getting in here?
Maybe. I thought I locked up.
You've been a little preoccupied, haven't you?
"A little" preoccupied? That's an understatement.
Is something wrong? You seem a little... abrupt.
It's nothing you need to worry about, Kirishima.
Whatever it is, I can handle it.
What do you need, Kirishima?
I was just trying to find Augie. He's gone missing.
By "missing", do you mean "in the radio room, without you, just like he has been for days now?"
... With Savary-san, yes.
She's more scared of you than you are of her.
I understand, Kanchou.
Considering that you called Belles sinking "murder" earlier....
I mean, it is murder! And it's wrong, and it's *stupid,* and-
Well, there you go. You're not really equipped to help with this one.
... More sunk Belles?
Mm. The Germans sunk a British sub called the Starfish. They claim they thought she was Starvation.
... That's horrible, but I could see how they could make that mistake.
And the French sunk a German munitions ship. She was a civilian ship, the Annegret. *They* claim *they* thought she was Disease.
... What is the world coming to?

Fields.MenuText: Hell, presumably.
If I figure it out, you'll be the first to know.
The world's seen dark times before.

Fields.DialogueText: Yeah, but not like this.
Even before Mr. McPhee? You really trust me.
Well, you'll crawl through the vents and find where I've written it down. Whether I like it or not.
Heehee. I can't *deny* that...
I feel like hell would be warmer.
And the demons would be cuter than Morganas.
Mmm. They'd want you to obey them.
That's what people said every time. No one ever predicted mustard gas. Or machine guns. Or ten-pounders.
Cavemen probably never guessed they could kill someone with a rock until they did it.
Maybe that's so, but...
*ALARM*
Get to the engine room.
Hai, Kanchou! And--
Mm?
If you ever need to talk about any of this stuff... I'm here.
I appreciate it.
@BATTLE
Dank dir, Lew. Ich hoffe, dass es nicht zum Äußersten kommen wird.
Gern geschehen. Ich halte meine Ohren auf. Und grüß deine Mechanikerfreundin von mir.
Who was that?
One of my contacts back on land.
Mm. Radio chatter, or something I need to keep an eye on?
A little of both.
... Is that so?
Wegrzyn's a ... what's the English word... an air spotter.
He's been keeping an eye out for the Sin planes. And I've been checking to see if he's seen anything.
Well, has he?
Nee. He's seen something more concerning.

Fields.MenuText: I'm struggling to think of what's more concerning than a Morgana carrier.
Is it anything we can solve with shooting?
Concerning? Do I need to be worried?

Fields.DialogueText: Depends. Do you want me to talk "politics?"
Probably not, Kapitän. Are you going to be angry if I talk about it anyway?
Well. Maybe it's not as concerning for you. It's "politics" again.
Don't beat around the bush.
Everyone's blaming us for the Morganas. ... Us Jews, I mean. You expect that after a while.
... But you hope they don't decide they have enough proof to do anything about it.
And you've heard they have?
Apparently, they're saying someone pulled a list off a Morgana. Couple hundred Jewish family names. The Rothschilds at the top.
Oh, brother.
They're saying that the Morganas are promising to "restore them to their past glories."  And that we're all collaborators.
Seriously, after Heligoland, Berlin's desperate to muddy the waters. "Germany's not colluding with the Morganas! You know who is? Jews!"
People are willing to believe anything if it gives them an easy target.
How can they not see that this is patently--
Oh, are you telling the Capitaine about the list?
Not you too.
"Not me too?"
New rule around the ship - no off-hand talk about conspiracy theories. Let's not give this any oxygen among the crew.
It's not like they can't hear it from German radio. If you listen in the mess, you can already hear the whispers. "Is this true?" "Does this hold any water?"
And you're telling them it's a lie, right?
Certainement. But you know what they say about lies. Before the truth has her knickers on-
*ALARM*
Cassel, if you weren't running out of your headache pills, I'd ask for one.
They wouldn't do you any good.
@BATTLE
Huh. Curiously, they haven't reported that to the League commission that literally exists to investigate charges of collusion in the area.
Ja. Very curious.
Can't you see that this is more important?
*Everything* is more important to you than I am right now!
"Right now," we have the fate of the world on our shoulders--
The world can rest for half an hour, Augie.
And you can't?
You said you'd like to go on a date with me five days ago-
The next time we're in port!
When was the last time we were in port?
Sayako, please-
You told me you *like* me.
I do! Believe me, I really do.
You can't even spare five minutes to watch the sunset?
I wouldn't be able to enjoy it.
Even if I was there?
... Even you couldn't distract me. There's too much going on.
You're not our Kanchou. You can put some of it down.
Heck, Kanchou *does* put some of it down! You've seen how much time the Belles-
What's going on?
.... Oh, Kanchou! It's nothing major.

Fields.MenuText: I hear someone shouting my name across the deck, I assume things are on fire.
Is that so?
If it's not, then don't yell.

Fields.DialogueText: ...It really isn't anything you need to worry about. We were just... discussing something.
N-no, easy mistake to make! Nothing's on fire.
I- I understand, Kanchou.
Mm! And it ... it's sad, but it's not... the end of the world.
*Sigh*
*ALARM*
*ALARM*
...Please don't say that again.
Stations, people! --Kirishima, now might be the time to yell.
EVERYONE! WE HAVE HOSTILES APPROACHING!
... That girl's impossible.
@BATTLE
Oh? Is that letter for me?
No, it's one of mine. Why do you ask?
It's from... from...
From Mrs. Verbiest. Fanny. Yeah.
I guess I should have known.
She sends you her love.
Wait, open displays of sentiment? Maybe you should ask her to blink three times, see if she's being held hostage.
I don't think anyone's tied her to the railroad tracks.
Did she say anything important?

Fields.MenuText: "Important" as in "about you"?
"Important" as in about the war?
Why are you asking?

Fields.DialogueText: I don't know. I guess-- you've been talking to her more than anyone else on this boat has.
If she had something she needed us to know... I figured you'd be the first to hear.
...That's not really what I meant, but...
Then what did you mean?
I guess... I meant anything she thought I'd need to know.
... Well, you said she sent me her love. I didn't want to assume she said more than that.
... Sorry, Kirishima. No dice.
Most of what she sent me was answers to questions I'd asked her.
Spy stuff?

Fields.MenuText: You could call it that, yeah. Either way...

Fields.DialogueText: Not to be shared. I get it.
Wish I had more to give you.
... Can you send her my love back?
Course. Is there anything specific-
*ALARM*
IT'S A LITTLE HARD TO THINK OF ANYTHING RIGHT NOW!
So save it for after the battle!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Yeah. And she's helping me squeeze a new toy out of some mad scientists. You'll like that one.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't tease me!
Radio detection system stuff. Supposed to be particularly sensitive to the materials Morgana planes are made of.
Sugoi....
Our mutual friend knows some very interesting people.
But I *have* been trying to follow up on the "Rothschild list." According to Fanny, the Germans are swearing it's real, and that the League will get access once they've secured the accused.
Ew.
Yeah. She's promised to arrange for a little more fact-finding.
About how the Nazis gave us an Indian summer?
No comment.
We've got another situation?
That's an understatement.
Walk me through it.
Well, there's still fog of war. You know how these things go.
But the situation out there is... bad.
Isn't it always.
You want the short version?
Give me whatever we've got time for.
The Soviets are saying the Finns fired on them on purpose. The Finns are saying the Soviets are lying.
One of the strongest Belles in the Baltic has gone AWOL, and the Sins picked off the stragglers.
A couple hours ago, we got a Finnish merchant convoy going through the Sea of Åland.
Three ships, with two escorts. One of which was Aura II.
The Finnish presidential yacht?
That's the one. She's supposed to be crazy strong.  Between you, me, and the ears in the walls...
She's also a little... too enthusiastic.
...I see. Trigger-happy?
Something like that.
Anyway. A Soviet sub surfaces right next to them. Aura fires on her.
You think she thought they were going to breach neutrality?
The land war's going strong. Maybe she thought they were going to attack.
Maybe she saw the Sins coming, shot, and missed.
Good grief. Not *those* Sins?
Afraid so. The Soviet ship ran, the convoy scattered, and I hear Aura teleported away.
Last anyone saw of her, she was on fire and her stern got ripped off. Looks like she tripped over her own torpedo.

Fields.MenuText: Have they tried to find Aura yet? Maybe she can tell them more.
I guess we'll just have to pick up the slack.
The last thing we needed was another international incident.

Fields.DialogueText: Everyone's been looking, but no one's seen her.
President Ståhlberg's phone's going to be be on fire for the next six hours, isn't it?
You say that every time something goes wrong. Don't get a hero complex on me.
And yet here we are.
At least this one wasn't our fault.
You know what they say about having greatness thrust upon you.
Mmm.
Humanity really can't afford a two-front war.
If we don't do something about this, that's what we're going to get.
You're still part of your navy, Captain. Who are they going to ask you to shoot?
*ALARM*
Right now? They want me to shoot Morganas.
For once, that's the right call.
Is it ever the *wrong* call?
Might have been for Aura II.
@BATTLE
... Kuso. That won't work.
What won't?
Oh, Kanchou. ... Can you turn the ship... maaaaybe 90 degrees? And get the lifeboats ready?
Lifeboats? What did you do?
I haven't done anything! Yet.
"Yet?" How worried do I need to be?
On a scale from one to ten? Zero.
So why the lifeboats?
You know that wrecked Avarice we keep sailing past?
Mmhm. It's been here for weeks now.
I want to board it. We need more photographs of the inside of Morganas-

Fields.MenuText: Do we really need the lifeboats for that?
Absolutely not.
Why? Don't you see enough of them every day?

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I'm trying to figure out how to board her safely. And if we need to escape--
Awww, Kanchou... It'll only take a couple minutes.
Well, yeah, but there's a difference between seeing them and studying them!
Is there any such thing as "safely" boarding a Morgana?
Nope! But there's unsafety and unsafety.
I can't endanger the ship or the crew like that.
What's the difference?
Twenty minutes of staring.
She's a wreck, Captain! It's not like I'm trying to board a live one.
Don't you have contacts who can get you photos like this?
... I mean, I *had* them.
... The war? I'm so sorry.
Chotto... It's not like that.
Then what is it like?
Mr. Lugin has been harder to find than a halfway decent bag of konpeito...
Yeah, I've been wondering about that.
... Which means I can't find any of his exciting friends to give me new pictures.
And then my other contact, Mr. Wegyrzyn...
Where have I heard that name before?
... He's also one of Augie's contacts.
Ah. Is he, uh...
Hai. He's busy right now, too. And for the same reasons.
They're doing important work.
I get it. I really do.
... Mostly I just hate that I don't feel like I'm allowed to be upset about it.

Fields.MenuText: You're allowed to be upset.
Have you talked to him about this?
Take it up with a priest.

Fields.DialogueText: ... I feel like I'm not.
There isn't a pastor OR a shinshoku aboard, Captain.
Mm, I have.
He's ...  He's talked to me, you know. About... everything that's been going on.
It keeps me up at night. If he hadn't come aboard with us...
He's a smart man. I'm sure he'd be fine.
...I hope so. Anyway, the point is, everyone I could get help from is busy.
*CRASH!*
*ALARM*
... Oh, no. The Morganas shot wide, and now...
You lost your wreck.
Everything's just going wrong today!

Fields.MenuText: Look on the bright side. Soon, you'll have a couple more.

Fields.DialogueText: @BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: We can ask a Belle to dive when the shooting stops. No hypothermia worries there.

Fields.DialogueText: ... Permission to hug you?
Not the right time.
Just a minute, Cassel. I need to read through these before I sign off on any of them.
Understood. There's not that many aid requests.
There's enough.

Fields.MenuText: I see one of your contacts wants an escort back to Amsterdam?
You've got friends in a town that needs help rebuilding after a raid?
You've got a friend who wants to sign on with us?

Fields.DialogueText: Mm. He's an engineer-
Good grief. At this point, we're drowning in engineers.
-- and he was a gunner's mate in the Great War.
..I'll get him the enlistment papers ASAP. The paperwork might be an issue, but...
We're patrolling past Gdansk anyway. It's en route.
It'll depend on how many Morganas we run into between here and there. If we need to resupply...
Ja, I understand.
Ja. He's a transport ship Kapitän. He's a good man.
Is he one of your friends from your diamond-selling days?
Bah, diamonds. He was, yes.
I'll see what I can do.
That's all I can ask of you.
Capitaine! My contacts have some requests for us-
Not you too!
Qu'est-que c'est? I only said-
Your contacts are incredibly demanding. Lugin's contacts haven't asked us for a thing.
Lugin's contacts are getting paid for their efforts. Handsomely, I might add. -- Where is that horrible little man, anyway?
I haven't seen him in days.
This ship isn't that big. He's around here somewhere.
If you find him, can you ask him where he left the hundred Mark he owes me?
You loaned him a hundred marks?
It was right after he came aboard. I should have known better.
You're never going to see them again, I hope you know.
*ALARM*
... Well, there go all my friends' hopes and dreams.
How do you figure?
If Morganas attack while there's something on the Captain's desk? You're never going to see it again.
@BATTLE
Brrr... it's so cold out here I can see my breath.
You think this is bad, you should try spending New Year's in Novosibirsk.
... I didn't realize you were out here.
Ne volnuytesʹ! I was enjoying a cigarette, that's all. You want one?
Mm... I don't know about that...
More for me, then.
Did your man in Peking get those photos?
My... oh, Anatoly! Nyet, I'm sorry, he's been very busy.
Ahhh, don't give me that look, solnyshko. You're better off staying cheerful.
It's hard to be cheerful right now.
Mmm. The curse of wisdom, would you call it?
What?
The more you know, the less you can ignore. The less you can ignore...
The more you start talking like a philosopher! Or getting sea-knee-deep drunk. One of the two.
... Heh. I can guess which you like better.
I'm from California. This is so cold I think I might turn into a snowman.
Ah, California. I knew a man from California. Said it was the worst place on Earth.
He must have been from up north.
Have I become that predictable in my old age?
No, you just always smell like gin.

Fields.MenuText: How long have you two been out here?
Lugin! I've been looking for you everywhere!
Kirishima! Can I steal you for a minute?

Fields.DialogueText: Nyet, Kapitän. I have already stolen her.
"She" can go where she likes.
And "everywhere" is where I have not been.
I'd really rather not-
A while. I have fire at my fingertips, we're fine.
Lugin, you goose. It's too cold for a cigarette to keep you warm.
*ALARM*
Lugin? Can you come down with me to-
-- ?? He's already gone...
Sometimes I wonder if our Belle taught him to teleport.
What kind of ship would he even be?
A scruffy one, no doubt. Get to your station, Kirishima!
@BATTLE
Absolutely not.
We've been over this, Herr Doktor. Alcohol is no treatment for frostbite.
I'm not saying they should drink while running around naked on deck to keep themselves warm! But when they're inside recovering it's stupidly bad for morale to ban it.
And if that "help" is no help at all?
There you go again.
We have men coming in every hour with a cold-related injury.
Yes. And that's because we're on a drafty barge in a sub-Arctic hellscape. You may not have noticed.
I heard shouting. Is this bloodsports, or is something wrong?
Bloodsport. She's trying to take my whiskey again.
Don't make me laugh! At this point I'm just trying to keep him from using it on the patients.
If we're trying to warm them up-
- the last thing we need is to further constrict their blood vessels.

Fields.MenuText: Whoa, hold your horses. Our Medical Officer's right.
Doctor van Geffen's right. This is dangerous.

Fields.DialogueText: Danke schön. You see?
Thank you. See, what have I been saying?
-- If nothing else, the alcohol might convince our sailors to get looked at.
We can't take more risks with the crew's health than we're already taking.
... Klar. But so might opium.
It's - what do you call it- preventative care.
It most certainly is NOT.
Can it, you two.
Kapitein-
The radio's saying this is the coldest winter anyone can remember.
You two are our last best line of defense against that cold.
Stop fighting each other and fight the enemy.
... You've been talking to the League again, haven't you?
How could you tell?
You're giving a unity speech again.
... That would do it.
Look on the bright side, Captain. For once, your speeches might work.
Oh? And why's that?
Because Hell's frozen over.
*ALARM*
Perhaps the Nixen are attracted to terrible jokes.
@BATTLE
It'd explain why they go after us so much.
We all need help to make it through this insanity.
There you are. I've been looking all over for you.
Oh, Kapitän. If this is about the munitions, I can explain--
It's not.
Blyat. And here I thought we were going to have a pleasant conversation.
It's hard to when it's twenty below freezing.
Hence the engine room.
Mm. Lugin, we've really needed you the past couple weeks.
You've said that several times, and every time it becomes less convincing.
We've really been struggling. I can't be everywhere at once, and we don't have many native Russian speakers aboard.
As much as you hate it, you're the best man for the job.
"Hate" is not the word I'd use.

Fields.MenuText: What are you afraid of, Lugin?
What word would you use?
If this was any less critical, you'd be in the brig right now.

Fields.DialogueText: You're very perceptive, Kapitän. Have you ever thought about a career in the NKVD?
As wild as it might seem, I *like* my job.
That's more than I can say.
Well, I don't like to put too many words to an ineffable feeling...
It's a powerful enough feeling you don't want to do your job.
I'd rather be there than here. No offense.
That can be arranged, you know.
If I were you, I wouldn't make empty threats.
... Let's look into the truth's eyes, for once. I don't want to be recognized.
Recognized?
I've crossed paths with some of these people before. They don't like me. I don't like them.
You don't have to like them--
If that was the only problem, I'd get by.
Then what is?
You're incredibly willing to take on deserters.

Fields.MenuText: ... Ah. And you don't want that to become a problem?
Why do I get the feeling that this isn't the whole story?
It's necessary right now. That doesn't mean I like it.

Fields.DialogueText: Because it never is! You haven't even heard about the time I spent working on a tea plantation in Kwangchow--
You've never worked a day in your life.
Of course. You take your duties very seriously.
There was a time when I did too.
It has been a problem from the moment you pointed me at the Krasnyy flot and said "shoot".
It will continue to be a problem until you get another translator aboard.
You've got to do this. We don't have a choice. If you're worried about crossing old enemies - you don't want to use your real name, you want to wear a fake mustache, knock yourself out.
If we want peace in the Baltic--
Hahahahahahahahaha! Oh, Kapitän.
You're deluding yourself if you think that you can change the course of *one* empire.
There's two here. And a third that would love a piece of the pie.
Then I'll just say this. If you can't do your job, don't waste your time hiding from people doing their jobs. If you want to opt out, you can just get off my boat.
We need you. We can't spare you. But if you can't do this, and you can't work on the deck, and you can't work a gun-
*ALARM*
Do you need me to prove my worth, or can I go?
You're dismissed. We'll discuss this later.
Oh, *goody*.
@BATTLE
I know that.
Then you know you can't afford to be naive.
Fine. Byt' po semu. This is all bullshit, Kapitän. Ripe, unfiltered shit, straight from the bowels of the finest Russian  bovines. And you know it's bullshit.
Talk all you like about your bullshit future, we're living in the bullshit now.
They're using you for cover. The hero of humanity, Kapitän Shtúka! See, the Kapitän agrees with us! They've done nothing!
Stalin will do what he wants, and if you squawk, you're a traitor.
I'm not. We're under attack by God knows what from God knows where. They don't stay dead, there are more of them every month, they can apparently brainwash people-
I see only one chance any of us have of having a future.
Move a hundred kilometers inland?
No. *That's* naive. If we want to survive this, we work with people we can't stand, we share information, and we hit them as hard as we can while we still have the resources to do it.
I don't have a fantasy that it'll be easy. I don't even know if it's possible! But I know if we don't try, it's over. So I'm trying, Lugin, and I expect my people to try too!
I can't believe I'm out of cigarettes for this.
Lugin.
I'm deadly serious, Kapitän. If you don't do something about this, I'm going to leave.
Cassel...
... You were willing to take on Russian deserters. Is there any particular reason you won't take on Jewish refugees?
They're not refugees. They're detainees. I've petitioned for access on behalf of the League investigation, but the Germans aren't budging. They say they're getting confessions.
Natürlich! They're very good at that!
But you know those confessions have nothing to do with actual guilt! You know it!
Two hundred people get arrested with only two things in common. One, they're all members of the intelligentsia.
Two, most of them are Jews.
There were a couple Catholic priests in there too.
Mm. You're missing the point.

Fields.MenuText: No, I see your point. I just don't agree.
... I want to hope for the best, even if we have to prepare for the worst.
The point is, some of your contacts are going to need to leave the country very quickly.

Fields.DialogueText: Then I'm not going to be able to stay. If I can't do good here-
The worst is here, Kapitän. We prepare for it, or we die.
Yes. I'm glad you understand.
Hear me out, Cassel.
Let me finish, please.
I understand, and I want to help. But.
Even if it's as bad as you're afraid it is -
This is a pogrom.
To hell with that! And to hell with the League!
August, they're not wrong! Yesterday we burned through more ammo than we did at the entire Battle of Rotterdam - that's our new normal!
... Apologies. It's just... these people need help. You see that, right?
... Give me three days.
We don't have that kind of time. You know they're being tortured, at best.
You want me to complain? You want me to leak what's going on to the press? I have and I will and it doesn't matter.
We *don't* know that. The confessions could be forged rather than coerced.
Listen: three days. I'll get in touch with the League, find out where they're being kept, push for access. I swear-
... I suppose that's more than most other Kapitäne would do.
You're a good man, and you know how to cut through Morgana interference like nobody's business. I'd hate to lose you.
And I'd hate to leave. But if I can't do any good here-
It's not really my business, but... have you talked to Sayako about all this?
... How did you... forget it. No, she has enough problems of her own. But that doesn't matter.
If there's somewhere I can do more good-
*ALARM*
Think it over before you give me your resignation. And give me those three days.
... I'll try to trust you that far.
@BATTLE
But what do you want me to do about it? They're not on a life raft! They're not lining up on a dock where we can swoop in and rescue them!
When I bring it to the League, they say they're negotiating with the Germans, and the best *we* can do is keep on fighting the damn Morganas while the people on land do their jobs. And they're not-
I don't know why the Morganas suddenly decided they want into the Oder, but our first job is to keep them out and to save the civilian lives that-
The civilian lives that *matter*.
Not what I was going to say.
When will you get it through your head that what you say isn't as important as what you do?!

Fields.MenuText: You're coming really close to insubordination.
Ouch.

Fields.DialogueText: Ugh.
Something wrong, Savary?
Nothing in particular. I just got off the phone with a contact.
And you don't like this person?
You know how priests are. He doesn't approve of my choices, I don't approve of his.
Mm. You hear anything good?
Pas vraiment. It's mostly gossip. Some could be useful, but only if it becomes the truth.
There's a fine line there, isn't there?
True, true enough. I meant to ask...
Mm? What about?
Cassel. He gave you an ultimatum, didn't he?
He tell you, or did you figure it out on your own?
A little of both. He made some... comments. You know the sort.
I do. Any chance you could help talk him down?
If you can't, I don't know who can.

Fields.MenuText: You know I'm not some kind of god of friendship and negotiation, right?
I think he's being perfectly sensible about this. In his shoes...
You probably would have an easier time. Or Kirishima.

Fields.DialogueText: I think I'd probably do worse. Maybe go on a hunger strike.
Hah! Cassel's an idealist, Capitain. He'd leave any woman behind to protect what he cares about.
Everyone else seems to think you are. Why not ask you to play the part?
Is that so?
And he cares about his people. He's like you that way.
He's right in thinking that innocent people - people a lot like his family - are in danger. If we're not trying to prevent that kind of thing, I don't know what the hell we're doing out here at all.
Well, I think--
*ALARM*
Hold that thought. We've got company.
@BATTLE
You wanted drinks with me, Captain? You're braver than I thought.
I didn't want *drinks*, exactly. I know you're busy.
Understatement of the century.
Thought the enticement of alcohol would get you up here.
You thought right.
So what did you want, if it wasn't conviviality?
I'd ask for your advice, but you won't give it.
You don't need *my* advice. You've been making all the right calls. I've been hiding from a woman half my height.
Call it a reality check, then.
If you thought I had to choose between my duty and doing the right thing, which would you say I'd pick?
You'd do what you thought was right. Every time.
You're a little quick to choose, there.
You break the rules, no matter what rules they give you.
Now I feel like a fool for asking.
If you ask me if water is wet next...
Heh. Or if Belles are crazy?
There you go. That's my Captain.
... Here's the real question, then.
Shoot.
For most of this war, my duty and the right thing have been the same.
Izzat so.

Fields.MenuText: What's best for humanity is what's best for the INPF.
My motherland can't thrive if the Morganas raze it.
My duty's to *people*, first and foremost. You know?

Fields.DialogueText: If you say so, Captain.
You make a damn good point.
I do. You have a soft heart. Especially for a Navy officer.
... This is the first time where nothing lines up.
We're five months into this, and you're only hitting that point now?
Yeah. Normally, I know what I have to do.
Getting everyone else to buy in is the hard part.
Ain't it always.
...This time, I'm not sure if anyone's going to buy in except Cassel.
He's infected you with his persecution complex.
It's not a complex if you're being persecuted.
So what's the problem, then?
... You just proved my point.

Fields.MenuText: I didn't want to believe Cassel, because the things he's saying... If they were true...

Fields.DialogueText: But if he knows what's going on, if he's not just getting twitchy... the right thing to do is to fight it. Tooth and nail.
....That kind of murder, on the grand scale? It's just as much a threat to humanity as the Morganas. Maybe even more so.
... But there's only so many times I can call the League and the newspapers and shout about fair play before I'm just a joke. Hell, maybe we're there already.
And if we want to keep people's eyes on the Morgana war, that's not good news.
So, what can you do instead of calling and shouting?
*ALARM*
... Ugh. We better hope this battle doesn't last too long.
I thought you wanted this conversation to be over?
I really did. But more battles means more frostbite.
Which means more work for me.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure you've heard the stories out of Poland. Jews being forced out of homes and businesses. Labor camps.

Fields.DialogueText: August thinks that's just the tip of the iceberg-
Insert captain of the Titanic joke here.
I'm sorry to be the one to tell you, but you're not as funny as you think you are.
I could tell myself it wasn't my problem - or at least it was low on my list of problems. But now they're rounding up people and saying they're conspiring with Morganas?

Fields.MenuText: And it's the sort of thing that leads to treason charges and quick executions.
I might be the one person in the world best positioned to call bullshit on that.
That's going to blow back on the war effort. It already is.

Fields.DialogueText: Hell, they may even have gotten the idea from the League commission!
You disagree?
I mean, between battles, I'm out here listening to Soviet officials promising that Väinämöinen could prove the Finns are colluding with the Morganas if I could just find her.
And the Germans are trying to say with straight faces that they have reason to believe that Polish Jews were collaborating with the Morganas in August.
But, hey, we can't talk about how Morgana weather-mod technology ended up in a concrete bunker in a little German island at the edge of North Sea. Nothing to see there!
The fact that you're frustrated doesn't mean you aren't doing anything about it.
I have good news and bad news.
Even the good news is bad news these days.
Which do you want to hear first?
Give me the bad.
... One of my contacts happens to live in Poland. Her home overlooks a square in the center of the city.
The past couple mornings, she's seen firing squads in that square. And some of the prisoners... they matched the description of people who've...
I'm so sorry.
... Don't apologize. I can't reassure you.
Je comprends. I'll give you a moment.
... What's the good news?
The Pope's denounced Germany. Specifically, what they've done in Poland.
And what's that got to do with the price of fish?
Most of my contacts are Catholic. Twisting their arms is easier than you'd think if the Pope gets involved.
I've managed to *convince* some port authorities to look the other way. If we're going to smuggle people...
What's this I hear about smuggling? Have you been talking to Lugin again?
Pas de tout. We're... discussing Cassel's contacts.
Have you made a decision, Kapitän? About the "situation"?

Fields.MenuText: I've been talking to INPF higher-ups. Nothing yet.
Yes. But I need some time to follow through.
You're the best radio operator we've got. I can't lose you.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you. But that doesn't answer my question.
... Danke schön. You won't regret this, Kapitän.
... That's what I was afraid of.
*ALARM*
I just need a little more time.
Ah, oui. The one thing that's never been on our side.
There's a lot more than one thing.
We'll manage.
@BATTLE
You wanted to speak with me privately?
Yes. Sit down? I can pour you a drink if you-
No, thank you. What's going on?
I have a couple questions. First... how are your headaches?
They get worse with stress. As you can imagine...
Sorry to hear that.
It's the strangest thing, though. I complained about the shortages, but lately... the Doctor's just had enough of my pills.
Huh. Wonder how that happened.
Maybe someone's made himself useful for once.
Mm. My other question...
Ja?
Are you willing to trust me?
To be perfectly honest with you? No.
Well, I appreciate the honesty.
In my experience, there's three kinds of people in the world.
People who hurt Jews, people who will wring their hands and watch it happen, and people who will do something to stop it.
... Yes, and?
You're the second kind, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sorry you think so.
You know I'm Jewish, right?
Go on. I'm not gonna toss you out on your ear.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm sorry. That honestly makes it worse.
I don't think you're a bad person. Just...
Overwhelmed. And too willing to shake hands with monsters. Even some of the Belles...
I asked you to give me three days. I'm asking you to give me one more.
You're not going to get the League to say yes to anything you're asking. You know that, right?
Yes. So I'm going to stick my neck out for you.
I don't want you to "stick your neck out." I want to save innocent people, and I think that this system that we're a part of isn't going to let that happen.
Maybe. I hope not, but maybe.
Give me one more day anyway. And if you don't like what you see tomorrow...
I'll relieve you of your duties, and drop you off at the next port.
... I don't want to leave, you know.
I thought - I still want to think - that I can do more good here than anywhere else.
And I'll give you the chance to.
*ALARM*
... Back to work, then?
Of course. -- Cassel?
Mm?
I'm not infallible. I haven't done everything right. You've got good reasons to be angry. But I've never lied to you, ever, and I'm not starting now.
I'll hold you to that, Kapitän.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Yeah. Maybe you're right.
You're right about the exhausted part, anyway.
August, sincerely, if you think you can do the job better, you're welcome to try.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't think you can change that. You're going to try to make things better from inside, and it'll just break your heart over and over again.
All right, people. We've got new orders.
We've got to extract some VIPs from Danzig and bring them to a safe port.
This mission's top-secret. It's critical you don't discuss it with anyone.
Wait, Danzig? The radio guy's been going on about-
Yes.
But they're-
This is an order, Yeoman. Finish that sentence however you want, but be ready to suffer the consequences.
Anyone aboard my boat can have whatever "opinions" they want. I'm your Captain, not your monarch.
But these people have been accused of a serious crime with no evidence.
Oh, and they're to be treated well. I called them VIPs. I meant it.
And let me just add that one of our top experts on Morgana aircraft is in danger because of this idiocy. So it's for the war effort on top of every other concern.
This is our duty, and we're gonna do it. Everyone, back to work.
Oh, and one more thing - run the League flag, and take down the national one.
... I didn't think you'd do it.
I almost didn't. Never mind the politics of it, organizing a jailbreak from the middle of the Baltic isn't as easy as you'd think.
They're registering Jewish property? Ja.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure they'll be seizing it soon enough.
The world's eyes are on us. We have to take a stand.
... What you said about the three kinds of people, it stuck with me.

Fields.DialogueText: Good. I wanted it to stick in your craw.
And you know that'll be just another step to something worse.
Yeah. And none of us can stop it.
... You're still stuck in "giving a speech to the crew" gear, huh?
Sorry. Force of habit.
Well, it did. Enough that I did something about it.
... I don't expect you to do this every time. I know you're probably going to let me down at some point.
Believe it or not, this wasn't just about you. But, yes, there won't always be rabbits I can pull out of my hat.
... But I didn't expect you to do it this time. And you did. So.
I can't make promises. But I intend to try.
*ALARM*
On your order, Captain.
You've heard the latest out of Danzig, I suppose?
@BATTLE
It so happens that that's a crime we have a League mandate to investigate. So we're getting the accused for questioning - at gunpoint, if necessary.
... And you're using League credentials to do this?
Yeah. Yeah, that's not going to go over well with Berlin at all.

Fields.MenuText: Can't be helped.
But, screw it. It beats implicitly *backing* them under the League flag.
Heh.

Fields.DialogueText: This is LNBC, I repeat, this is LNBC, calling D4MJS, do you copy?
D4MJS, this is LNBC, calling D4MJS.
Any sign of our VIPs?
No. But there's a metric ton of interference.
You think it's from --
The Sins? Yes.
There's been planes circling all morning, Kanchou. It looks like they're waiting to drop-
FWWWWSHHHHHH-
-- Their payload!
D4MJS? Can you hear me? Do you copy?
What's that falling from the sky? It's not bombs.
... Looks like... sheets of paper?
This one's in Polish... that one's in German...
It's just paper?
You'd better get a look at this, Captain.
... This is horribly misspelled. I can't make head or tail of it.
To make a tedious, rambling bit of nonsense short...
This one says that Morganas are the destroying angel and anyone killed by one goes to Heaven. This one says that Jews are collaborating with Morganas...
Ugh.
It's propaganda. All of it.
*Badly-spelled* propaganda. The worst kind.
It'll get better, Captain. You know how these things go.

Fields.MenuText: Kirishima- clean up the papers. Now.
It will, and we'll counter it.
Don't borrow trouble. We can ignore it for the moment.

Fields.DialogueText: You seem focused.
Hai, Kanchou!
If you say so, Captain.
I'm trying to stay quiet so Cassel can find our VIPs.
*BOOM*
That won't do us much good.
Stations, people! Open fire!
@BATTLE
D4MJS? Do you copy? If you're out there, please-
LNBC? LNBC? QRZ D4MJS 800 kilohertz-
Is that our VIPs?
Ja! Give me a second.
What're they saying?
They're telling us where they are.
Stay in contact. Don't let the signal get away--
I'm trying! There's a lot of interference!
*KSSSSHT* Hive *KKSSSHT* consume--

Fields.MenuText: Well, that's unsettling.
The hell is that? Where is it coming from?
Don't lose the VIPs. We can't afford-

Fields.DialogueText: Don't nag me, Kapitän. We're almost-
No clue, but it's blocking-
Ja, and it's getting in the way of our signal.
*BOOM!*
Morganas again! Let's give them hell.
@BATTLE
We've reached the coordinates. Where are your friends?
I'm radioing them again.
LNBC!! We see you. Can you see us?
Wegrzyn, you needle in a haystack! We see you. We're coming.
Baruch ha-Shem. There's so many ghost ships. We've been hiding for days.
Well, we're here now. Let's get you aboard.
We're ready for you. There's just one thing-

Fields.MenuText: Lay it on us.
What's the hold-up?
Let me guess, you need a favor?

Fields.DialogueText: We've got some old folks and children. It's going to take a while to get everyone aboard...
Well, not exactly.
We've got old folks and children aboard. And one of the kids picked up a puppy somewhere...
We need a minute to get them both aboard.
Roger that. We'll hold our position.
You really are military, aren't you?
Roger. We can hold our position.
Thank you, Captain. We'll do our best to stay out of your way.
Do your best to help, where you can.
I think it'll turn out to be the same thing, in the end.
It wasn't for me.

Fields.MenuText: What can I say?
I wasn't six months ago. It just creeps up on you.
Let's save the small talk for when everybody's safe.

Fields.DialogueText: We're lucky to have an excuse to get out of here.
Out of where, Savary?
Out of this miserable, godforsaken sea.
Is that so?
Surely you have eyes.
In the last twenty-four hours, we've sailed past three Soviet-Finnish engagements...
At least six German ships, one of which was coming back from the English Channel for repairs...
-- And that's not even counting the Morganas.

Fields.MenuText: Another beautiful day in the Baltic.
That's the new normal.
I hate it too, but that's the war.

Fields.DialogueText: I never said it wasn't. It's why I'm glad to be leaving.
You always look on the bright side of life, don't you?
Or the funny one.
... It's not going to be much better anywhere else.
Je la connais. But it's still...
... There's something oddly satisfying about it, isn't there? Leaving them all to go to hell?
For once, you don't have to save them from their mistakes.

Fields.MenuText: Oh, I still feel like I have to. That's the problem.
Now that you mention it, it is a relief.
I just wish so many people weren't getting caught in the crossfire.

Fields.DialogueText: Mon dieu, you have a savior complex.
I wish I could say the same.
If they had the power to get behind the lines, do you think they'd give different orders?
Does it still count as a complex if I don't have the first damn clue how to be a savior?
No matter where we go next, you'll find some fool problem to stick your nose into.
I'd like to think that, yes.
*ALARM*
Here's another reason to get out of the Baltic.
It's this bad everywhere, you know.
It might be "this bad", but it's less crowded.
@BATTLE
Well, that's it. The League has spoken. We are officially banished from the Baltic Sea.
Ah, oui?
The League says it's the only chance they've got to keep the Baltic Commission going - the Germans are threatening to completely suspend cooperation.
So, yes, we're now officially doing the cause of unity more harm than good - and it's a Latin American goodwill tour... or something.
Their story is that we just proved that the entire thing was a pretext for the League meddling in German affairs. Hell, they're grumbling about pulling out of the INPF altogether.
You look like death, Cassel.
It's no good. I did everything I could.
Six hours of negotiations, and for what?

Fields.MenuText: You did your best.
You can't draw blood from a stone, Cassel.
Nothing. Which is more than I thought they'd give us.

Fields.DialogueText: "My best" isn't going to give any of these people a place to stay.
I expected we'd at least get some rainwater. You're the 'hero of humanity' and all.
...Didn't expect you, of all people, to get cynical.
They wouldn't take *any* refugees, then?
Not one. I tried to haggle them down to just the children, but...
I thought you were a salesman.
I hate sales! I'm only good at selling people things they already want.
Like selling heiresses diamonds?
Mm. Or like selling you hope.
Fair.
So what happens now?
Mm. I don't like having civilians aboard--
... Ja. I was afraid you'd say that.
But as someone said, I made my bed, and now I must cry in it.
You mean--
I don't know where the League will assign us next. But I'm going to do my damnedest, wherever we make port next...
To find your people, not just a place to stay, but a *home*.
... Thank you, Kapitän, but I wouldn't bet the farm on it.
No?
At the *best* of times, no one wants to take a bunch of refugees. And these aren't the best of times.
But there's children-
Jewish children.
That shouldn't make a difference.
You know full well "should" isn't even worth a reichsmark.
They treat us like rats, Kapitän. If a ship full of rats sails into your port, you let them into your port?

Fields.MenuText: People aren't rats.
I had a pet rat when I was small. They get bad press, that's all.
I see your point, but...

Fields.DialogueText: ... Hope that's not how you see me, Kapitän.
No, I was going along with your metaphor.
They sure see us that way.
Then there's something wrong with *them*.
You know what your problem is, Kapitän? You expect everyone to be a good person.
There are worse problems you could have.
That's not the point, though.
Then what is?
... We've seen it the past few months. The world's full of bastards. But it's also full of people like you.
You dropped your entire life to do what was right for humanity.
That wasn't much of a sacrifice.
Still. You didn't have to do this. ... We've just got to find someone with as much...
Humanity?
Something like that.
They don't put people like that in charge, Kapitän. You're a fluke.
*ALARM*
Lucky for us I came along, then.
@BATTLE
More drinks? Either you're trying to buy me off, or you're on the verge of a nervous breakdown.
Neither. Mostly I wanted to thank you for your advice.
Thank me? For pity's sake.
You took my advice. Now your name is mud.
It's more complicated than that. On both fronts.
Is it, really? They kicked us out to the back of beyond--
I hear the Falklands are lovely, this time of year. You know they have penguins?
You know as well as I do that they're not sending us there for the penguins.
You pissed off more people than usual this week.
... If they're going to make me someone else's problem, then I'll oblige.
You think they've caught on yet? That you'll be a problem no matter where they put you?

Fields.MenuText: I have no idea.
Let's hope not. I want to keep at it.
Oh, absolutely. They put me at the back of beyond for a reason.

Fields.DialogueText: And you're already figuring out how to cause trouble in exile.
Something like that.
Knowing you, you will even after they catch on.
I'm not causing problems on purpose. I'm trying to solve them.
Pleading ignorance, Captain? That only gets you so far...
It's not like I'm on trial. I got off with a slap on the wrist.
Yeah, that sounds like you.
I'm surprised you're not happier about this, Doctor. It should be easier to get all your favourite things closer to the source.
Cocaine, sure. Morphine's from the other side of the goddamn planet. And as for booze-
Fair enough.
... It's not as bad as it could be, though.  Not by a long shot.
No. I hear they're putting Ferneck in charge.
He's a sensible man, and his Belle's...
If you try to call that girl "sensible," I'm gonna die laughing.
No. But she's got good intentions and a decent head on her shoulders.
I don't know if anyone can save the Baltic. But I can trust them to at least keep things from getting worse.
Is that what you were trying to do? Save the Baltic?
Save the world, more or less.
You regret it?

Fields.MenuText: I'd do it all again, the same way.
I wish I hadn't tried to ignore the politics, but...
Absolutely. But there were no good choices here.

Fields.DialogueText: There never are good choices. There's just choices.
Decisive little bugger, aren't you.
Everyone tried to warn you.
Mm. And I didn't listen.
Mm. Is that supposed to be comforting?
You know it.
*ALARM*
Doctor, we're going into combat.
So?
So put the bottles down.
Ah, Captain, don't be so harsh. There's a lot of ways to use a wine bottle in combat.
Improvised weapon... painkiller...  shield...
Or one-way ticket to the brig.
@BATTLE
Oh, Mr. Lugin! Have you got a light?
Yeshche by. But I thought you didn't smoke.
I thought I'd try something new. Besides, they say it's good for the nerves.
And yours are shot?
I don't. But...
After the last couple weeks?
I'd be surprised if anyone aboard had nerves that work. ...Except maybe our Belle.
Nonsense. My hands are steady as the Captain's reputation.
Heehee. Then mine are too.
Say, I hate to ask...
But I saw you and your "special pal" coming out of the broom closet this morning...
"Special-"
Your dear, sweet, darling Augie.
It's not like that! We uh. I'm not sure where we're at.
Oh, I'm certain, I'm certain. It's none of my-
He said that he needs to focus on work and that we should just be friends. And then he said that-
Blyat.
He said that he liked me and that he wanted to be more than friends someday but maybe-
Kirishima, Kirishima! It's the same old story. You don't need to justify yourself to me.
Justify...?
Everyone has... what do you call them... boy problems.
... I just... we were in the closet, yeah, but...
I really don't care about the gory details. You make your own choices.
... If you don't care, then why were you asking?
It is none of my business who you are fooling around with, or how foolish that fooling turns out to be.
It is my business if you are fooling around on top of a sack of dubious explosives.
Dubious explosives?
It's better to ask the Captain's forgiveness than permission. And sometimes, while waiting for that forgiveness... things go into places they shouldn't be.
... What's that glint in your eye, solnyshko?
What? Nothing, nothing!
Mmm. At least one of us is staying cheerful.
Ack! These cigarettes are strong.
Strong enough to put hair on your chest.
Ew. Maybe I should kick this habit before it starts.
Once you've had a taste, you can't go back.
The curse of wisdom again.
Something like that.
... I kept thinking about that. What you said.
Da?
I thought the Captain would manage it. Save the world. Save Augie's friends. Get them all to Rotterdam.
Make Augie smile again. You know.
Two out of four is... odds the Kapitän would bet on.
Most of it happened! But it didn't... change anything.
It never does.
He keeps telling me- August, I mean- that we can't save the world.
But that we saved his people. And that that's good enough.
I'd commend him for his clarity, but then I might run into the Kapitän.
Mm. You think he's right, then?
If the world doesn't want to be saved, what use is there in saving it?
I don't know. But things have to get better than this.
Oh, they can always get worse.
I was afraid you'd say that...
Look on the bright side, solnyshko. At least we're going somewhere warm.
*ALARM*
Oh, gosh, I've got to get to the engine room. Hey, Mr. Lugin?
Da?
Thank you for telling me about the explosives. I think they'll come in handy.
... Oh, what have I done...
@BATTLE
The Morganas have been eliminated, and we're on course, Kapitän. A few days out from port.

Fields.MenuText: Good. We all need to rest and resupply.

Fields.DialogueText: You can say that again. I'm just glad we made it here in one piece.

Fields.MenuText: Knock on wood.
We always do.
Cassel! I thought you trusted me more than that.

Fields.DialogueText: I trust you with my life. I don't trust the Morganas.
Fair enough.
Everyone always does, until they don't.
Superstitious, Kapitän?
Only sometimes. ...But we know magic is real now, don't we?
Fair, but-
*STATIC*
Verdammt.
Lookout! Tell us what you're seeing.
The horizon's clear, Captain!
*STATIC* writhing.... crawling...
Cassel, isolate-
Already on it, Kapitän.
-- under [STATIC] skin. The flies come first--
[STATIC] -- lay their eggs in your eyes--[STATIC]
-- Now I wish I hadn't.
Keep listening. This could be important.
-- the Worms. [STATIC] The Worms. I can feel them. They coil around my spine, moist and fleshy--
[STATIC] -- nothing left of me. I'm warning you-- [STATIC]
[STATIC] - prerecorded message. Ships are warned to [STATIC] Fernando de Noronha--
[STATIC]
Signal's gone, Kapitän. I'm trying to boost it, but--
Fernando de Noronha, huh...
Ach... Kapitän, I see that look...
You're scheming.
I'm not scheming. I'm thinking.
With you, it amounts to the same thing.
I don't like it. Worms? Eugh.
I don't either. And we've got to get your friends off this boat before we can do anything about it.
... I know they sent us to the back of beyond to keep me away from the action...
But it looks like the action's coming to us, whether we like it or not.
I think we need to find the source of that signal.

Fields.MenuText: Good. Then we can start working on finding a proper advocate for our guests.

Fields.DialogueText: In what sense?
Somebody who can make a legal case for why these people need protection wherever we end up. Or somebody who knows who to bribe. At this point I'm not feeling picky.
